column11: Review Text

column8: Decent place to buy local products . Just remember to bargain as it is expected
column11: Great place to visit to buy curry, tea , spices and local souvenirs. It can be overpowering to visitors but walk in with a purpose and choose a stall you would like to visit and buy your produce from it . Just remember to bargain and yes the prices will be higher if you are a visitors , just like any of the attractions you visit in the country . It is what it is when you visit many countries and just buy the produce if you wish to do so as it is your cultural immersion .

Take a tour of it for sure, an experience that puts you in touch with the local people and the various cultural differences. I also recommend tasting different types of fruit, while for tourists I would avoid meat and fish. Try it! You will be immersed in the real Sri Lanka. I leave here the number and name of our guide in Kandy: it will not disappoint you and above all it will not trap you in the usual tourist traps. We've grown attached! Roshan: +94 76 349 8276
We were so disappointed with the Kandy markets. It was priced for tourists and was very dirty. Essentially overpriced street stalls in a smelly setting.

Nr 42, the best place for your spices and tea! Super friendly guy, not pushy al all. You can take a look, he gives you information, you can smell different kinds. When we bought some products, he gave us a very good price. We got it wrapped up in some schoolworks paper from his son. We had a good laugh, super friendly guy who helps you with a big smile. My trip is almost over, and I regret not buying more at his stand. He had really good products. Go bring him a visit!

column8: Great market and Cafe was nice!
column11: The Kandy Market Hall is lively and full of shops offering everything from trinkets and clothing to souvenirs, fruits teas and spices. Among them, Shop 42 stands out as the top spot for spices. The quality is excellent, the prices are reasonable. Marzook, the owner, was so friendly and helpful. We‚Äôre very pleased with our purchase and would highly recommend Shop 42 to everyone.

column8: Avoid at all cost - if you are a tourist
column11: Super annoying area. If you look like a tourist, you will be swarmed by market sellers, asking you to buy their goods. If you are not foreign-looking, maybe you can enjoy the market, but otherwise, stay away. There are better things to do in Kandy.

I most certainly would return to Kandy Market and everything else in Kandy.  There is just so much that's great about Kandy there's not enough space here to tell all. The market is awesome, the people are just amazingly friendly and helpful without being pushy. The Temple of the Tooth is sacred and beautiful, the lake is lovely.  The war grave very interesting, the Kandian dancing show & fire walk so colourful and amazing.  So much wildlife too. No one can go there and not fall in love not only with Kandy but the whole country.

column8: Bank 42. Reception honesty and a lot of heart
column11: Looking for spices and tea to bring as a gift to Italy I visited almost all the spice stalls inside the market building. On the first floor I found Marzook, a special person who loves his land and ce.la.fa love. In a few minutes you understand that he is not a seller like others but.that respects tourists and does not take advantage of it. In fact, try to help you in every way with a nice and friendly act. A person of heart.  I took the tube packs of spices and the tea and it's all very good and tasteful Thanks Marzook. n 42
This market looks and feels a genuine local one, even if it is defintely also aimed at tourists too; you can buy lots of things, from bags to cinnamon, at prices that are still reasonable.

Central Market is abuzz with all sorts of shops selling trinkets, clothes, souvenirs and spices. Shop 42 is the best place to buy spices. The quality is good and the owner Mr Mazrouf is an extremely courteous person.The price is good and the packaging excellent.  Very happy with our buy , would recommend shop 42 to all.
Attention rip-off - a person pretends to be a hotel employee that they know you and persuades you to buy overpriced products.
Nice place. The seller was very polite and helpfull.we were a  group of 6 and he had time and patience for everyone. We found some spices and vanilla product.

Lots of great shopping options for souvenirs of all kinds: tea, spices, fruit, handicrafts. Some grocery shopping as well. Things may be pricier than elsewhere but it was so convenient to find everything in one spot we didn't look anywhere else. I highly recommend shop #22, who had a great variety of teas and sold them to us at a good price. We did all our souvenir shopping here, super convenient. At the back is a fish market so can be a bit smelly.
Shope no 42. All spices and essential oils are very good quality.  Got cinnamon and Ceylon tea and green tea as well. The shop owner is a very courteous man and have me aloe cream as a gift.

The market is worth a visit for unique souvenirs.  The usual souvenirs and beautiful leather goods. It was a lot smaller than I expected.  The fruit/snacks and spices are on the ground level, with 1 jewellery, a few clothes and tri kets shops on level 2. Beautiful pashminas and linen clothing. The prices are OK until you haggle down to about half. Then they are really reasonable. The building is situated on a very busy corner and was very smelly outside. There is a toilet where they ask 2 Rupees to use. Take coins as your 100 note disappears like lightning and he doesn't understand when you ask for change haha. Most shops take cards and the owners are lovely and accomodating. Overall worth a visit, but I read the reviews here and didn't buy any spices.

Thank you to Sekar in 28th place, for making the market visit an unforgettable experience, good Pro, thank you for your kindness and your advice, definitely recommended. By the way, I took vanilla, cinnamon, essential oils...

Great to see the fruit, veg and meat side of the market. That was interesting with riots of colour and smells not too mention the traders shouting out their wares. The upper floors had clothing and spices and these seemed expensive in comparison to street traders and other shops. Spices were pre packed in sausage shaped bags.....this means you couldn't guage the freshness. Glad we popped in for a visit though
Busy, dirty market. Nice to see but I wouldn¬¥t want to buy any food there, in certain meat. Flies and crows everywhere :D But it was fun to see at least :)

We stumbled over the market hall and after traveling all of Sri Lanka we can now confidentially say that this is the place to buy your souvenirs. We bought up big but wished we had bought more! They are cheaper than anywhere else in Sri Lanka and they do bargain. Definitely stay a night or take a few hours to buy your souvenirs!!!
Situated in the heart of the  city in a colonial-style. Offering a wide range of local items. Narrow and a bit crowded. It provides a great shopping experience to all kinds of travelers.

This belongs to the Kandy City Council and they have much vegetables fruits, spices, clothing, tea and bags. It seemed like the vegetables and rice was stacked up in huge bags and I could see people very busy getting them of the trucks.

A visit to the Kandy market is highly recommended, especially the fruit and vegetable area, which is very lively, with a spectacular offering and numerous local buyers. Also the one with fish and meat... The latter quite impressive, with the entrails washed and exposed to dry in the outside patio, and the crows prowling around. The spice shop area may be more conventional and touristy, but it is still interesting and has more reasonable prices than the shops that organized tours take you to. Specifically, we made some purchases in store No. 42 (Marzook), where a very kind young man treated us exquisitely, always with a smile, and explained to us the characteristics and properties of the products he offered in his store. After some haggling, we ended up purchasing some spices and cosmetic products, and as we were leaving he even offered us a small gift. On the other hand, the tourist souvenir area of the market seemed unnecessary to me, but it is worth taking a look around the entire area. All in all, it was a fun and very interesting experience that allowed you to do some shopping and calmly interact with the local population.

Magnificent acquaintance with Mr. Marzook! His shop exceeds all expectations, he pays attention to the smallest details, he knows how to best advise you and the prices are more than honest.. Marzook is not only an excellent seller, but also a friend, we asked him for various advice and he took us to heart and gave us the best advice. He even gave us some nutmegs because we took a liking to them! We also took: curry leaves, vanilla and coconut oil for the body/hair, we can't wait to bring everything with us to Italy and use them to the fullest. We will think of you dear Marzook! A kiss
We went to the kandy market hall and due to another review went to No. 42 and it is indeed the best shop for spices with regard to prices and choice. Would definitely come again.

Kandy market is a must-see when visiting Kandy. The market is offering the best Sri Lanka has to offer: beautiful fruits and vegetables, tea, spices, herbal oils, silk, everything you can imagine, and all at fair prices. The colours and sounds will blow your socks off, so get your camera ready. We have visited the market in March 2023 and have done extensive shopping at the shop number 28, named Authentic Sri Lankan Ayurveda, owned by T.H.M. Rishard, where we got an excellent deal for a selection of souvenirs, tea, oils and cream (of course, negotiation is required). Please note that the prices were much, much better than in Prince Herbal and Spice Garden in Sigiriya, where we basically got ripped off. Before shopping, make sure you spend some time just roaming around and taking in the atmosphere. The same like other open markets across the globe, this is the place where you can feel the real beat of local life.

I heard from locals that the place is very nice to look at, but that the prices are a scam and that it's better to just buy whatever in a supermarket. Because of that, I didn't buy anything at the market. But to experience its atmosphere and to see what everything can be bought at the market in Kandy, the place works wonderfully and you can freely roam around.

Buy in a supermarket! You can see the prices.  Inspect the goods. I am very annoyed that I allowed myself to be cheated at the Spice Stall. Unfortunately, the worker started talking in 1000s (thousands) when up go that point I had been used to thinking in 100s (hundreds) of rupees. I paid much more than I should have. 12500 rupees for goods worth 2400 rupees or less.  When I later translated the cost into English pounds ¬£30, I realised the extent to which I had been ripped off.

I got all the gifts I wanted to bring back and a lot more stuff on top of that. It felt like everything had a price tag on it, so it wasn‚Äôt necessary to haggle too Much, although you clearly can if you‚Äôd like to.  Quite a few shops sell similar items but overall there is a great diversity at the market.  Fun to see the fishmongers and butchers in back and small retailers up front as well. Someone else had mentioned stall 42 on here. I stopped by there, and felt like I was well taken care of. Those guys are super friendly and I can recommend them as well.

Going to the market hall was one of the most genuine experience that we had. Moreover, there you can buy fruit, spices and souvenirs for the best price! It‚Äôs full of locals and tells you are on the right spot. We had an amazing experience in shop 28 with Rishard who explained to us all the different types of spices and teas. He extremely welcoming. Overall if you are looking for a genuine experience and to buy souvenirs or food for a good price this is the place to come!

This is a fun place to see all the trinkets but you will get ripped off‚Äîthe salesman are VERY good at haggling. If you REALLY want good tea and spices and the local rate, walk Colombo street between Kotugodella Veediya and Yatinuwara Veediya. That‚Äôs where you‚Äôll find the good stuff.

Please don‚Äôt waste your money at the spice garden like I did! Go directly to this market you can buy spices, yoga pants, silk scarves and so much more. You need to haggle. It is about 1/2 the list price. It is a fun experience. We bought so much stuff we needed to buy an extra duffel bag which luckily they also sell üòÑ Some comments store 1 is great they have beautiful silk scarves and will give a good price. Store 42 has great quality spices, creams and incense sticks reasonable prices. On the 2nd floor store 201 has great yoga pants, beautiful marble elephants and they accept credit cards! Don‚Äôt miss out!

This place sells gorgeous products: spices, pepper, vanilla and a vast selection of oils. The guy who works there took time to explain the characteristics of each thing sold and, though not cheap, we found the shop excellent to buy local products.

Ranjana's Tourist Store Kandy, shop nr 201,202, 1st floor What a great surprise. Ranjana's shop in Kandy Market Hall has some really nice merchandise. A correct price, and a very nice, sweet service from Salvem and his wife Priya. My husband had a lot of yoga clothes made to measure and I bought nice pants and had some dresses made to measure. Perfectly made and very fast. We went in 2015 and 2016 and I now know that if I came back to Sri Lanka my first stop would definitely be with Salvem and Priya again. Mieke and Urbain

the central market is something that you have to visit, specially the MARZOOK shop, there you have all kind of spices and teas in a big variety of formats perfect for a smalls presents, at the same time you will enjoy the shopping with these funny guy thaks a lot :)

NUMBER 42. Amazing place for variety of teas, mango, passion fruit, golden tips green and more rare teas! Lots of oils, spices and creams, powders, seeds, real vanilla beans! Nice wonderful people working there!! Essential oils, caco powder, so many teas!! Even strawberry! You can smell them all! Hair and massage oils, incense sticks and more! Such a friendly guy working with perfect English! Fun guy, Sri Lanka toothpaste (it's good) local bee honey, saffron and of course local cinimun! Come by it's worth it, cheapest prices in town for the same stuff sold in the center.

Amazing shop and Rishard is really nice and helpful! He offers products that are similar to those of the spice garden, but with lower prices! He‚Äôs focusing on customer service, without being pushy. You can find all you need. Recommend this place!
Haven't tried their product but they offered reasonable price. Much cheaper than Spice Garden. Good service. Look for Rishard.
I bought there fake products :/ sandal Wood Oil is unauthorized and really bad quality. Avoid this place
We were so pleased over the spices and services offered by the owner of shop 42. Highly recommended üëç

Passing by the market? A must visit is stall number 42, Rashid from this stall is one of the most helpful people on my trip. We had bought a lot of tea, herbs, and extracts from here. While comparing prices in the market around, rashid had the most compelling prices. Additionally, he had a lot of interesting background stories, about each tea. A must visit, you won‚Äôt regret it.

Shop no 42 was recommended to us by a guy who worked in the hotel we stayed at. We are glad he brought us there! Rishard, the owner, gave us an excellent service and a really good time at the store. We received some tea, bananas, mangos, and we laughed a lot! We bought spices and tea in a really good price (we had bought some earlier in the Spice Garden where we had paid almost 3 times more!) This was a great market experience and Rishard is such a kind, welcoming and friendly person.

It‚Äôs a nice little market with a lot of great things to buy for little money. You should absolutely go there. We were at shop 42 and the owner there was so kind. He told us about everything and was so friendly. :)

A guy told us to go to Kandy Market Hall because there you can buy everything you want for very good prices. He showed us shop Nr. 42. At first we were a little sceptical but the owner of the shop showed and explained us everything about his products, gave us fresh tea, mangos and bananas and he was just lovely. He also went to a ayurvedic massage studio wirh us, which was 10 minutes away from the central and waited for us until we were finished. You just have to visit him at his shop!

If you want to get the real market experience, this is the best place to go for, Kandy is known as the last kingdom in Sri Lanka and It really it worth to visit, most of the things are cheap but don't buy spices from this place as those things are overpriced
highly recommend shop no 42 for its great variety of spices, reasonable prices and quality goods and service. Though there are quite a few spice shops in kandy, shop 42 offers the best price ever.

If you are looking for spices, tea and herbs I can strongly recommend the local shop N¬∞43 at the central market hall of Kandy. The shop owner Rizwan has proven to be an excellent ambassador of Sri Lanka ! He offered us to taste different kind of tea's and has helped to choose a selection of local brands. His good sense of humor contributed to an overall pleasant experience ! Service at this shop is TOP !

Nr 42 shop only! Found it by reading reviews on trip advisor  Richard is an amazing guy - you will get answer for everything you are asking. Was pretty hard to find it but that's why I will upload his photo so everyone can recognise him. Nice little shop with loads of tees, coffees and other thingies. When you will come to the market other guys will try to block you and suggest to go to their shop but just find the way to shop 42! Compliments!

I am so happy that I went in to this shop! Richard, the ovner of the shop is an totally fantastic person. He is really friendly, smart and chill man. He sell all the things you need, spices, tea, oil and the quality is absolute amazing! He also had a tuktuk and took us around! He is a unike human beeing.  Glad I become friend with him! He know all you need to know about Kandy, and he know alot of great people if you need som help! Just go and you want regret! Thanks Richard!
You can buy your souvenirs at a reasonable price (don't forget to bargain). Many stalls of spices with good price (bargain again). We enjoyed the time spent there.

Shop 42 has amazing spices, tea and oils for a very fair price. The shop owner, Rishard is super friendly and accomodating. Would highly recommend. Rishard also helped organise us a massage, driver for the day and food recommendations, he even invited us to his home and arranged to cook for us. He made our time in Kandy incredible.

There are many places at this market for buying spices, teas and this kind of things, but this place is special. The owner is not pushing. He takes his time with explaining you the usefulness of the spices.. the price is reasonable and at the same time  you get a nice smile :) Highly recommend.

We wanted to go to shop #42 because of all the good reviews but we didn't find the owner very friendly. But Aqthab from shop #1 is awesome! He is very laid back and great to talk to. Plus he's the only one at the market who sells fresh ground spices from his hometown in stead of pre-packed ones. We spent half an hour at his shop and had a great experience. Definitely go to this shop!
If you want to buy teas, spices and oils go to this store. The owner is very friendly and available without the usual pressure of the obligatory purchase and still with great prices!

If u are trying to find the best tea shop with someone on the other side to help u choose the best without having that feeling that hes just wants to sell, this is the shop. Mr Rishard was always very kind, helpful and very polite.

If you want to buy teas, spices and oils go to the N.42 Central Market store, it's the best place, very friendly and available owner, explains everything without the usual pressure of the obligatory purchase.

It is definitely a nice place to visit, taking it all in, the stall vendors can get a little pushy (especially in the clothing section). For us the clothing wasn‚Äôt available in the bigger sizes, which was shame, as the shirts were very nice. Also be-aware of the hard sell, (remember, you only pay to much for something, if you feel you are paying to much for something, just say no  thankyou, and move on). We found for easy (no fuss)  shopping the likes of LUV SL Kandy (see review) fixed price, was more suitable, for tourists.

The best place in Kandy market hall to buy tea, spices, herbal remedies. The owners of the shop are extremely generous, courteous and honest.  We were served different kinds of tea's for us to try and the owners give you a detailed explanation of the products. They also helped us out in identifying the difference in the quality of the spices, teas, etc. Prices are VERY reasonable and they will go above and beyond for you. We were there for Sri Lanka new year and all money exchanges were closed, they exchanged our money for us at a better rate than the market. What else could one ask for? I would highly recommend No.42 for your spice, tea, and herbal remedy needs. Non pushy store owners who care about their customers. Love it!

The central market is very crowded and messy place. However we arrived in by Chance!! too many staffs and sellers offer their goods. sorts of confusing!!. we randomly chose No. 42 and found fantastic seller guy.  he offered us a cup of tea with ginger and cardamom. such a beautiful aroma and taste. he patiently introduced his spices, herbal oil, gel and cream and with a great deal. without forcing us to buy the stuffs. Thanks man.... we will come back again to your stall for the next time...

This market offers a wide range of goods. It didnt feel entirely safe but was an interesting place to explore. We were tired and didnt realise until later quite how much we'd paid for some clothing and the linen wasnt linen and the silk wasnt silk.  Buyer beware
I never miss any market whichever place i visit,same here. A great Lankan market with all kinds of spices and fruits . Had a great shopping at a reasonable price.

A busy local market which will give you a feel of local life. Please do not buy items from the first store you see. They will most probably overcharge you if you are a tourist so please check on the prices in a few shops before buying and negotiate further! We stopped by store No.42 where we ended up buying some items. The owner, Rishard and his staff, Marzook was there. I found Marzook friendly but Rishard was a little pushy. They were generally nice but it would have been better if they didn't start with such a high starting price as I had to negotiate hard. I don't recommend any specific store but walk around, ask a few stores for their prices and go with any store you feel comfortable with. Most of them sell similar stuff. The market has 2 floors. First floor is edibles like fruits, tea, spices, meat, fish etc. Upstairs is clothes, bags, wallets and a pharmacy.

We had a nice time visiting this marker. It showed quite some local culture, which we really enjoyed. Please think twice entering the first floor, because it is quite touristic. The ground floor is where the locals buy their food. Enjoy!

We bought some spices from spice garden almost 5 times expensive from here. After reading it on tripadvisor visited No:42, The owner Marzook was a nice guy. He sold us from fair prices but dont forget to bargain same as everywhere. Barzook on the picture.

Our  driver/guide brought us here and we were very pleased he did. He sought out stalls selling fruits, vegetables and sweets etc which we'd never ever seen before and the storekeepers were more than happy for us to taste their wares, and without charge. They all seemed very proud to show off their Sri Lanka produce. A colourful, vibrant, busy place, friendly and fascinating. Go if you are able but ensure you visit with someone local so that you can get the best from your visit. You may wish to avoid the butchers shops though, they are for strong stomachs only!

Went to No.42 after reading the reviews however after visiting we think the reviews must have been ‚Äòfriends‚Äô because we negotiated some Curry Spices which turned out to be nearly half the price in a local supermarket. So our advice is to check the cost in the supermarket first and then go to market so you know what the price range is before you hand over ur cash. Just some friendly advice because we believed the other reviews but would not believe ‚Äòblindly‚Äô again.

Market is OK.  It's no where near the markets of Thailand so don't go thinking it is. We visited stall 42 as seen on here.  Much cheaper than rip off spice gardens but one piece of advice, ask prices of each item before committing to it,  we ended up spending more than we would usually.  But this was our fault not the owner,  who is a lovely guy and will explain everything to you. Upstairs is a couple tourist stalls but nothing worth noting. Worth going to see locals shopping.

Yes it stinks in the fish section, and the meat market turned Mrs Johnson vegetarian, for 5 or so minutes. However, its quite a jolly place to wander around for half an hour, being harassed as usual by touts selling sh3t products. The spice man at 42 stall seemed to be OK, we will find out when we get home! Worth a wander through, certainly.

If you dont want to be a tourist victim,if you want to avoid tourist traps go to kandy market hall to number 42. Do not buy from Tea factorys do not buy from spice garden because you will pay switzerland prices and you are in sri lanka. So simple.

Kandy Central Market is a great for everything local. Go to shop no. 42 to buy spices and teas. Mazrook was amazing. He guided us with the best quality spices at reasonable prices. If you need spices or tea this is the place to go to. I purchased divine oily vanilla beans and fresh curcuma from here. Highly recommend this store!!
Local shopping area on very busy part of town. Crowded. Nothing unusual or interesting in my view. Usual hawkers and shops for locals.

Make sure you head for the ‚Äúlocal‚Äù building of the Central Market to avoid dodging the many tshirt/clothes salesmen who bother you. You can‚Äôt miss that you are in the right place as it is a quadrangle of fruit and veg stall with No.42 spice stall on the right as you enter. There are more stalls out of side doors and tailors etc on an upper quadrangle floor above. Nice guy in the spice stall. Very informative and friendly and (we think) he did us a reasonable deal. Worth a visit and definitely cheaper than Mathale gardens.

Next to the Hela Bojun Hala, is the city‚Äôs central market. It is a one stop shop to meet all vegetarian needs. Situated on either side of the entrance are several shops loaded with all kinds of fruits and vegetables. All of them were fresh, green and luscious. It is a visual colourful treat.

We had alot of time in sri lanka and boaght from alot of stores but the absolute best one was in kandy spice market shop #42 the seller richard was amazing very helpfull and very cheap prices with more discounts and gifts. We will deffinately go again and advise everyone to only buy spices from that store. A must go place

We were lucky our rickshaw driver cum tour guide took us to Kandy Markey Hall, this is where all the locals come for their shopping.... lots of shops selling a range of products... we got lucky at a lovey saree shop from where we picked up few good saree's as gifts...

Our bus back to the city from the Botanical Gardens deposited us right outside the market, near to the veg and fish stalls. The fish by afternoon was pretty stinky as you can imagine. We spent about 5 minutes just wandering through. If it hadn't been raining, I'd have got my camera out and snapped some of the fruit and veg merchants who were happy to tell me what their mysterious veg were without trying to sell me any. We really only scraped the surface of what they had to offer and didn't buy anything - we were just too busy trying to work out where we were and how to get to some place we could recognise. But landing at the market was a fun time.

The kandy market hall is a very good place to get some fresh fruits from Sri Lanka and you see many locals purchasing goods. We would specially recommend shop no.42 for spices and tea. The owner of the no. 42 was very knowledgable about the products, he gave us a perfect explanation on what we wanted. The spice tea was perfect. Things well packed as the customer require.. worth a visit to shop no. 42
Small market, most of the stalls are selling the same things. Again a place where they are good at persuading you to buy things you don‚Äôt even want.

is located in the Heart of town. Its worth a visit to see the colorful display of the Tropical Fresh Fruit stalls.Kandy Market  is a public municipal market which is close to the clock tower in the centre of the city. this large market area - it extends beyond the colonial era hall.

We were lucky enough to find a very good place to buy some good tea and spices. Was a bit tough as all the stalls look similar. We highly recommend to visit stall no. 42 owners were very kind and was able explain everything. Stall No: 42 is an ideal place to buy some good stuff for your loved ones at home. Prices were very reasonable too.

We were dropped outside this landmark by our driver, and expected to be hassled by stall owners. We both felt that this market one could breathe a touch easier than other markets located throughout Sri Lanka, and Kandy. If you're looking for Leather, clothes, spices or trinkets this is your place. It's also a place where some tailoring can be done if you so wish. Got some pants made upstairs and they ended being cheaper than they were down the road in a marketplace. You can circle this place realistically in under half an hour, but obviously if you are entering to do some shopping this time could exacerbate into Hours. Please enjoy,   We did, worth a visit if not two.

We visited this market in the afternoon and so trade in the food area was nearly over, but we love to look around at how the store holders present their wares. Downstairs was food and upstairs more shops that were selling everything from clothes, homewares to souvenirs. Only problem was the unwanted attention from the store holders trying to sell their wares to tourists! Drove us made and made us not buy anything. As we are from Australia, they got the message immediately that we could not take back any spices due to our custom laws and then were happy just to chat.

Searched up the markets location online and are glad we visited! Full of cool shops with a range of spices, fresh fruit and veg, bags, ornaments, gifts, there really is something for anyone looking for something to remember Sri Lanka by. The downstairs focuses on food items with the upstairs more on clothing and non-perishables. We managed to get some bargains for elephant trousers and little keepsakes, and even got some great deals on fresh spices. Now the thing to watch out for is tourist pricing. The vast majority of shops will have fake prices shown to take advantage of the tourists who visit. However we managed to find one shop who the owner was so genuine and offered us local prices from the offset. They all state they are offering local prices, but when your paying 50 rupees for a tube of cumin and 55 rupees for chilli powder, then you know it's much closer to local prices (Vs other shops selling for 150-200 per tube). Expect to bargain on most of the stores but also expect that some won't budge as I guess tourists are usually happily paying the higher prices. Definitely a must see if your in the area and in need for gifts!

July is off season so we got more attention from touts than you might normally.  We wanted to shop but were put off by our unwanted guides and companions.  We ended up walking away and shopping elsewhere.

Wander around the halls of the market! We bought awesome suvenir spices for very cheap. 200 rupees for a large bag of cinnamon, 150 rupees for a bag of curry. Cool thing was to wander deeper into the market, to see how the locals trade. A lot of fish, fresh meat, fruits (you have to try every fruit there is, yummy). Cool local experience. We spent half an hour there wandering around

Traditional market, targeting tourists, lots of haggling needed - can get down to 40-50% of the asking price. Recommend stall 22 for teas and spices as it uses fixed pricing and has a very knowledgeable and friendly owner selling high quality products
Good opp to stock up on souviners at reasonable prices rather than at the places your driver stops at that pretend to be hand made. You will get at a quarter of the price with a bit of negotiation.

This market is a great place to buy clothing, tea, spices and souvenir items. Prices start out a bit high but it isn‚Äôt too hard to negotiate up to 50% off the asking price, particularly in the late afternoon when many shopkeepers are packing up. Like any tourist market, some of the shopkeepers can be pushy and attempting to walk away is often the best way to get a good price. If you do a tour around Kandy to wood carving shops, tea factories and spice gardens, you will find many of the same items available at this market for less than half the price you will pay at the shops where your tour guide will take you. There are also a few food/drink shops and a bakery too. Well worth a look.

This is a busy local market with a large variety of goods. Spices and produce on the first floor and other goods (clothes etc) upstairs.  You have to bargain of course but you can get things for a good price. The building is a bit rundown but pretty with the garden in the centre.

While in Kandy don't forget to stock up on fresh fruit, and there are lots to choose from. The fruit section is just outside the main hall and is great for photography. I live in a country where apples and oranges are expensive so i bought many here at low prices.

It‚Äôs hot and sticky in here! Bargains galore but remember the game. They ask for a third, double even triple (as you‚Äôre a tourist) more than the price but what they‚Äôll settle for, is your job to bargain for hard...Work out what you think it‚Äôs worth and if they let you walk away you know you‚Äôre close. Rucksacks, bags, clothes, shoes, t-shirts, sarongs, pashminas, scarves galore! A good rucksack set me back 3000SKR but don‚Äôt be fooled by the brand names! Just have fun chatting to them and examining their wares. It‚Äôs a market! They want to do deals and SELL. They do get upset if you engage with no intentions of buying - I tried to be mindful of not getting sucked in and to be firm, but courteous to the more persistent traders. Then the food and spices part! Wet fish, dried fish, meat, fruit, veg and spices! (Not every day, check!!). There‚Äôs an underpass that connects the two!! Don‚Äôt risk your life trying to cross the road!!!!!!

If you need any of those things - go there. There is a really nice spice shop. Really reasonalble prices (haven't seen many other places). It's on the ground floor, is quite small and belongs to two brotheres. I believe the shop is called Mohamed :) This market has all the local things you need :)

In any town, the market is always my favorite place to see local life.  Kandy's Market Hall is no exception.  Downstairs is where local folks buy their veggies, fish, meat, etc.  It's hustle and bustle and fun to walk through.  Upstairs is more for buying clothes, medicine and crafts.  Many of the clothes in the US are made in Sri Lanka, so you can get a good deal on brands like North Face or Colombia here.  Of course, there is no guarantee that they are real, but I bought some nice pants and some shirts for about 1/4 what they would cost in the US.

The original central market of Kandy offers a neat quick walk-through. There are food and souvenir stands - nothing that we needed. It is always great to see how other cultures live. Some of the stands are definitely over priced and aimed at tourists, but you do get the opportunity to see locals doing their local things. And...I do not believe I had ever seen a dried fish stand - I would be interested in knowing what type of dishes dried fish is prepared with!

The market is standard, but good. Some items are over-prized, while others are cheaper than on the small streets outside. Don't skip the small streets opposite to the market, they sell a lot of clothes and scarfs. And is really local :-)

We spent an hour this afternoon walking around the food stalls at the Kandy market. It was great! So colourful and noises, we saw no other tourists. Locals were really friendly and didn‚Äôt mind us taking photos even though we didn‚Äôt buy anything except some coconuts to drink. The colours were stunning, locals explained what some of the exotic foods were that we hadn‚Äôt seen before. We felt safe throughout and enjoyed our visit. There are toilets there and many cash machines near by. We gave the clothes/homeware stalls a miss.

I went to this market and visited a shop. The shopkeeper looked very nice and introduced the products to me. He also showed me the comments from other travellers saying that they were nice and had good services..... I bought Ayurveda Balm from the shop at LKR 850 each. Then the man took me to another shop selling scarfs, and I bought the silk scarf at LKR 1900 each. They claimed that they gave me discount already. However, when I went to a supermarket, I found the Ayurveda Balm selilng at LKR 160 only!!! And I checked the ones I bought, I found that they erased the price printed on the packing!!!!! Later, I found the same silk scarf in Galle, and the price was only LKR 800!!!!!!! So, don't buy anything in the market, just visit and have a look is enough.

Kandy Central Market is located in the Heart of town. Its worth a visit to see the colourful display of the Tropical Fresh Fruit stalls.Sample some luscious mangoes.  Eye pleasing display of fresh Vegetable stalls. On the first floor one finds hand made real leather goods stores where prices are good. Items are durable.One Can buy Spices, Oils made out of spices and cinnamon. The Colourful batik Stores are also worth a visit. If you don't mind the wet and messy atmosphere the Fish and meat stall at the back can be visited. This is not for the light hearted. Don't expect the sterile look of a pharmacy but this is the real thing. I was amazed at how well the Central courtyard was maintained with rows of flowering bushes see picture. In the middle of the city chaos this fits in well

Kandy Market Hall is a public municipal market which is close to the clock tower in the centre of the city. The market is spread over two floors with a central inner courtyard with landscaped gardens of which I have never come across anything like before. The market was busy getting on with its day when I visited with stalls selling everything from and everyday necessities to the more unusual. It is a unique market and one not to be missed whilst in Kandy.

If you are lucky a local will spot you at the trainstation and brings you straight to the market. For sure the best place to buy all the healthy Ayervedic stuff you wanna bring home. And they now even have a service to deliver your goodies all the way to Europe.

this is a raucous and rowdy place - not for those looking for peace and tranquility. However, it gives you a sense of the pulse of life in kandy town. The fruit stores alone is a sight. I thought I have seen all types of tropical fruit but I found even more here. The meat and fish section of the market is a bit daunting but well worth the visit. if you have the time, don't miss this!

Great place to see foods you'll never see back in the USA!  Spices, fruits, meats, it's quite an experience.  Our guide took us through every inch of this large market area - it extends beyond the colonial era hall.

We like a market. UK or elsewhere, they are usually worth the time to take a look. This is the second Sri Lankan one we've been to, the previous one in Negombo, and the sights, smells, and sounds are an assault on the senses. You'll hardly be able to pass a single stall without an invitation to buy. It doesn't matter that you don't want spices, or that the carved wooden elephant would put you over the airline weight limit, the vendors will be on the attack! It's mostly friendly banter: "Where you from?" "We can do you a great price!" "Lovely leather bag, sir?" and a firm "No, thank you." is usually sufficient. They are often VERY persuasive though, so be aware. We found a great upstairs outlet selling local fabric. I bartered my way to a great deal on material to make into a bed throw and cushion covers, but my wife had spotted a gorgeous blue and gold sari that she needed for a wedding later in the year, so that was that! My mission then was to get a couple of wall hangings thrown in, which was managed (if you don't ask, you don't get..!) and we left the outlet some 8000 rupees lighter. [This equates to around ¬£40, and is a fraction of cost in Europe!] Immersing in the local experience is a great way of finding souvenirs and providing you keep your wits about you, you can spend as much and as little as you want. Enjoy!

First time visiting kandy, not much too do other than tooth temple and a lake near by weather pretty hot now in mid April,booked for 2 nights at ozo decent hotel , still looking out to do things and places to look out, Buddha statue some garden and national park with some money all get to see

When I visit a new city one of the first places I visit is the local market - its a great gauge of the town and is generally not so full of tourists. The municipal market in Kandy is built around a number of open courtyards, with areas for fish, meat, veg, spices etc,  The meat area is probably not for the faint of heart (or vegetarians) - but that's where meat comes from and that's what it looks like when its not portion-packed in Waitrose! I was after some vanilla beans - after looking round for while at some plastic wrapped small packs of thin beans, I was led into the back of a stall to be shown a box of paper-wrapped huge, fat, oily top notch beans. Done! Well worth a visit.

As markets go, it is aimed at locals and tourists. The second floor with clothes, leather products etc is probably more touristy. The ground floor has vegetables, spices, meat, fish anything food wise really.  It is OK to visit. They are not too pushy. If you have time, pop in.
Nice place, bit touristy, but everything singalese  you want to by is here for sale. Beware of raw greens. Do not eat and buy them.

This is an excellent place to buy Sri Lankan spices, such as curry leaves and special curry powders. We also bought caftans, and the lovely white cotton Sri Lankan shirts, all for a decent price. It's really busy and difficult to get around. I would have spent more time here but the constant activity was too much. The fish market really stinks.

At first the market seems a bit dull. Two floors surrounding a courtyard. However, once you take a closer and calmer look inside, they actually have a lot to offer. The best part or the most authentic part of the market is however just around the corner towards the back. Thete you will find out how meet and fish have been sold fir decades around the world. Some people are repulsed by the primitiveness of the situation, and call it unhygienic. I can't help but being admired at how a thriving market and people have prospered under the simplest of conditions. The meat and fish market are nor for the faint of heart, but it you're going to eat meat, at least understand what butchering looks like. And dont forget the fruit and veggie market, under a canopy of parasols, just a bit further out back. Be prepared to see a myriad of greens you are probably not familiar with at prices that seem ridiculously low. I highly recommend this all to real adventure.

This place caters for locals doing their fruit vegetable and meat/seafood shopping not to tourists. Yes it could be cleaner. If you find it dirty and unhygienic there is the supermarket around the corner. The full goats head was tempting for goats head curry lol. However there are some fantastic local fruits and vegetables I haven't seen anywhere else. How about cheese apples with texture like a cheesecake (the orange fruit in the picture), wood apples, different varieties of mangoes and passion fruits (both sweet and sour). On the veggie side, both green and purple wing beans. Buying the local yogurt or curd is also unique being sold in ceramic pots. It's right in the city centre so a quick easy walk. Some sellers can be quite persistent and occasionally overbearing and really want to sell spices to you but there are quite a few that aren't.
Really don't bother to go here. Place is smelly, unhygienic, and stuffed with bad food and ugly handbags, really disappointed at this place.

Clean and well presented market in beautiful arcade around a central garden. Food and spices on the ground floor and non-food goods on the first floor (mostly touristy stuff such as leather bags, clothes and souvenirs). Worth a brief stroll during a walk through Kandy's city center.
Tour of the markets whilst visiting Kandy City, this is were the locals cone to buy and sell there vegatables and fruit 6 days a week

After looking at many souvenir shops and Laksala's I was feeling dejected because I couldn't find a shop to buy decent souvenirs without being ripped off. This is my second trip to Sri Lanka so I had a good idea about prices. My last stop was at this market to check out Jayamali Batik on the second floor of the market. While he did have beautiful batik of very high quality I wanted something less pricey. He pointed me to a Ranjana's. I walked into the unassuming shop, no. 201 and 202 and  felt I was I hit the jackpot. I purchased a large mask dyed with natural dyes and many wood carvings, batik table cover, simple dress and two batik head covers, snow globes etc. All for USD 190. Selvam, the owner, helped me a lot along with his wife. They were friendly, honest and sweet. Please visit them if you are ever in the Market!

Despite the fact that it is also a famous attraction for tourists, the "backyard" or the less exposed area of the market provides plenty of opportunities both to do your veggies and fruits shopping (at a local price, no bargaining, no headache) and to enjoy the craziness of any local market. Another highlight is trying the local fruits. Go to the first stall on the right from the entrance and ask for Nissan and he'll give you passion fruit, avocados, mangoes, watermelon... you can have a second breakfast of the day. He likes talking to foreigners and chat for a while. And he's one of the nicest in the market as others will probably push you to buy or confront you if you're just "window- shopping". It's a nice place for a stop over and get some "fruit supplies" for the day.

We weren't sure what to expect from the market, we had a little look around the ground floor and a helpful gentleman, who said he was the manager, advised that there was clothing upstairs... we headed up and he started a conversation, we had a bit of a chat with him... had he left it there we'd have happily browsed and spent plenty of money but he was on us at every turn and made us feel slightly uncomfortable to the point where we made a couple of purchases and then left... tip to shop owners leave us to browse and we'll spend more money!!
Good to see the many varieties of fruits and vegetables on display and at very good prices. If you are squeamish do not walk through to the fish and meat section!

Kandy Market Hall has all kinds of shops, fruits, produce, meat, fish, grocery, spices, book shops, post office and many more for a reasonable price. If you are in Kandy this is the place for the food shopping.
If you want to fing good leather, tea, and shirts this is the place. You can buy cheap fruits and clothes.

Great market experience. Lots of locals come here to buy fruits and veggies on the ground floor. Second floor has more touristy items. We came here to buy cheap, fresh fruits, as well as spices/ Ayurvedic creams and oils / teas. We would highly recommend stall 22! The store has been in the family for three generations. Gives you fair prices. We bargained a little, but not much. Compared to other vendors, spice garden, tea factories, his prices are very reasonable. Do not go the vendor selling teas / spices / lotions on the second floor. We were conned by a man in the Kandy city centre. He said he was on his way to get a cup of tea at the market, and he would show us a great place to get spices. After having spoken to him about his family and work at length, we trusted him and followed. However, the prices of the store he brought us too were as much as 5x more than the stall downstairs, for the exact same products. Great place to buy things, but watch out for scammers. An unfortunate and disappointing experience, but there are still some friendly faces in the market.

I visited the Market hall as part of an overall trip to Kandy. It was an interesting experience, seeing all the produce and shops. I went especially to find fabric and I wasn't disappointed. Really fabulous material at great prices. I didn't stay too long in any other section as I wasn't interested in buying anything else but it was still good to see
Might suit someone interested in such things but I just wanted to have a look. If you are looking for T-shirts or tea or pictures of colourful fruit you're at the right place.
This isn't my kind of a place. Mostly it was interesting to see what they are selling and to experience (good and BAD) smells. It wasn't a place where I want to buy things.

We visited the Market Hall one morning to check out Jayamali Batiks. We weren't planning on buying anything else at the market as the quality didn't look so good. We came across this spice and oil shop and ended up buying a lot of things. Mohamed, shop keeper was very friendly and knew what he was talking about. Shop 22 is definitely worth a visit, so is the batiks shop there.
An interesting experience, even on a Sunday. Fish, vegetables, meat, betel nuts, and pretty much anything else you can think of.

If you get to Kandy on your Sri Lanka tour you have to visit the Central Market. The sights, sounds and smells are intoxicating. the market is lined with stalls selling all Sri Lanka souvenirs from cool local clothes to exotic spices like saffron. Test your haggling skills and you won't be disappointed!
It is a well organized market and a good place to shop for food and bric a brac. it is relatively clean and it makes it easy to shop. Yona s.
It is just another busy market and not very special but worth a visit to see how people go about their daily lives. There are touts so take care.
This is a nice market to get spices and other local stuff at good prices. This is very popular among tourist also.

This place is a heaven for bargain hunters looking to buy all sort of things made in Sri Lanka. We paid a visit to this place after finding artifacts and clothing to be very expensive at other stores in Kandy. We bought 5 Polo tshirts and a few souvenirs at extremely cheap rate. One tip for anyone looking to buy things here is to start negotiations at 25% of the stated values by the salesman. They usually tend to agree around 30% of the initial price offered. The quality and authenticity of the clothing is debatable but they do look nice for the price.
It is a local market where you can find tea and spices at a very good price. You can go there at the end of the day when it is quiet.
Unless you are into shabby chic, well just shabby really, I'd steer clear. It's pretty dirty and dingey. And red hot. I'd choose somewhere else to buy my meat or fish.

This is a great place to buy spices at very good prices.  It is a local market so can be busy but if you can negotiate local prices rather than tourist prices then you can get everything from fresh vanilla pods and paper still on the twig to ground spices ready mixed for authentic curries.  The adjoining textile market is also a great place for cheep clothes.

A great market - best bit is the covers market in the two story building as the rest just seems to sell t-shirts and saris.     But the spices, leather and (if you want it) the fruit and veg are all good.    The leather goods are far more varied and about half the price of the shops in town and more varied.   Leather wallet Sr 1,800 vs. Sr 4,000 in the town shops and a leather belt for Sr 800 ....... Very good value.

At this market I bought curry mixed spices, just for souvenir, not really knowing how to. I just understood that one package was for meat and the other for vegetables. At home I learned how to use it in diner by googleling and experimenting. It makes me very enthousiast. Next time, and there will sure be a next time, I buy them again an maybe more. I also bought vanilla but I could not keep that good until I was at home. So the dry stuff is sowieso okay.

Great market to see feel and smell all the produce of Sri Lanka. On the first floor level there are plenty of trinkets for tourists to get something small to bring home. If you don't need souvenirs skip it and head straight, for the fruit, vegetable and meat markets. So much fresh produce so beautifully presented. Great place for photo's and just seeing the hustle and bustle.
There is nothing to see here. It is dirty and it smells bad. Half shops were closed. Don't lose your time here.

Built in the late 50's this is  an imposing building whose environs spread over a vast area. The fruit stalls have a variety of hill country fruits, vegetable stalls, groceries, a post office, butchers shops, fish stalls. There is a bustling vendors market as an large outhouse to the main building specializing in vegetables. If you are on a self catering vacation this is a place worth shopping in.
I bought tea and vanilla here.  My husband also bought a few tops.  It was nice to walk around and talk to the people at the stalls.  A few people followed us wanting us to buy in their stalls.

This is a lovely place to haggle and buy spices in Kandy.  The smell of dried fish can be a bit overwhelming as in most Sri Lankan markets and so can the hassling tradespeople.  It does get quite hot and stuffy though, especially where the clothes are.

This is probably the best place to have nice walk around.Ground floor you can see vegetables, fruits and some spice shops.if you go further inside on ground floor your will very busy local vegetable market.it is nice because people will never push you follow you asking to buy things. If you go to 2nd floor then you will see all the hand crafts and suvonirs.

Well worth a visit and no hassles compared to many other countries. Good natured bargaining for quality cheap spices especially cinnamon, vanilla pods ..etc.. Also some upmarket batik as well as cheaper tourist goods. But really as much a local market which Is the main reason to visit.

The market is pulsating and exciting. Put on a smile, a positive attitude and get ready to experience some new fruits and spices. I bought some spices and tea at the market as well as a sarong (for wearing in the tooth temple). The sellers are a lot less aggressive than in other countries I have visited, which gave me a much better impression of the market. It is also a square garden in the middle making it feel less crowded. The second floor is mainly clothes/leathers/textiles, while the first floor is fruits/vegetables. To be honest, there was a lot of crap in the second floor such as fake t-shirts, however I suppose there is not a market in the world without these things... They also had some good fabrics, and the sellers seemed completely honest with regards to the qualities: They admitted what was woven/printed, silk vs polyester (I am not an expert though...).

You will get more than your 5 a day fruit and vegetables at the Kandy Market. The market is a hall like structure  surrounding an open, courtyard and cultivated garden where much of the produce is washed before being displayed. The smell of spices waft from the various stalls on the ground level, where you will also find an abundance of fresh fruit, herbs, vegetables, flowers, incense, utencils, fish and packaged foods. You will be amazed by the beauty, presentation and quality of the products on offer. The Sri Lankan diet is mainly vegetarian and very healthy. Food choices are often based on the medicinal properties from many of the plants, roots and herbs. Generally many Sri Lankan people would prefer natural remedies for various ailments. Ascend the stairs to the top level for local arts, batiks, crafts, linens, fashions, souvenirs ornaments and decorations. There are many treasures to be found. The total market area is large when you include the entrances, alcoves and exits which are sheltered under  natural canopies  to keep the sun out. These areas constitute the hub and have the buzz factor as people trip over each other for the best deals. You could easily spend a couple of hours enjoying the different sections of this market. Have yourself a fresh King Coconut drink and eat the inner flesh for a special treat. Dip into some fresh cashews and try some exotic fruits you will be delighted by the different flavours, smells and textures. If you are on tour, your guide will gladly take you upon request. Alternatively, catch a tuk tuk, local bus or taxi of which there are many. If central the cost to get there is low. Enjoy Lulu and Diddis market experience. There are also many other photos of Sri Lanka from the ruins to Ella Gap and Colombo. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9vW1OCzaBso
I didn't buy anything but it was such a beautifully built market with so many spices and fruits. Yumm!

We had a fun time buying bits and pieces in the market. We just went to buy some silk fabrics to upholster cushion back home (we do that in every country and we have piles of cushions as a wonderful memory of our world wondering). Anyway we always have our technique: one bargain the price and the other one says that he wants to go home because he is tired and not interested...it works all the time! We got beautiful silk at a really good price! Such fun! The structure of the market that opens on a courtyard is very nice and do not give that sense of claustrophobia that sometimes closed market can give. Nice experience.

It is a challenge to go through this place. People at the entrance are very aggressive, they yell at you and encourage you to buy. Once inside, it gets more normal. There are pushy people but the situation is more typical. You can find good fruit, some clothes. We were really curious and explored the place entirely in a rainy afternoon. The meat market stunned us, perhaps, that's why I was so reluctant to eat meat in Sri Lanka...

Had fun buying fake sports tops and scarfs as gifts and chatting to the locals. The market is split into several parts, the food and tourist bit in the old building by the station which has lots of touristy things to  buy and the clothes part near the WW1 war memorial and pedestrian under pass. Clean, tidy, easy to get around with some bargains to be had and freshly chopped pineapple to quench your thirst. All prices are negotiable and the quality of Western branded fakery if good. The stall holders were all pleasant and not too pushy. In the old hall up stairs watch out for people trying to show you around and then request money or a tip.

This is a lovely old market set around an open grass courtyard, which allows some breeze to circulate. The ground floor produce stalls are beautifully laid out and well stocked. However, if buying spices to take home we were told that you'll always get better quality and price at a good supermarket, which seems to be the case. The upper floor has the usual selection of clothing stalls, but the prices are very much higher than, for example, Thailand or Indonesia for the same items - perhaps 3 times the price. The traders complain loudly that it's all because of the tax they have to pay, but that's hardly the shopper's problem. Whatever else you do here, check out the metre long sticks of cinnamon - amazing!

We walked up from the train station to this bustling market of a mixture of delightful and questionabe smells and an array of colour and characters.  The first floor is where you will find great gift and memorable Sri Lankan items. Do shop hop before purchasing as it is small and you can then have more bargin power. Youwill be offered help fromeveryone who has a brother or uncle in themarket. I was looking for insense stick hholders,  by the time I had been to 2 shops everyone knew what I was looking for and I voting me to visit their friends shop. Lots of fun, not so pushy busy as some local markets.   My friend had the new shirt she bought tailored, a little, on the spot and I had some beautiful material made into a wrap skirt.

Fabulous fun. Step down into the market and you're immediately bombarded by someone who wants to sell you something at "a very good price"  Don't be afraid because bargaining is a must.  My friend saw a lovely elephant throw which she told me would look good in her sitting room.  We asked the price and he said 13,500 rupees.  We both laughed and walked away.  Going and looking elsewhere we saw this trader following us.  In the end after much haggling  we came to an agreement of 7,500.  He was happy and so were we.

Happen to passby and we visited here. we found rates are very low. purchased spices n tea which r much lower than those spice garden n tea factories. we got good deal in all goods. worth visiting. all locals purchased from this market only.
If you want spices find M. I. M Rizwan @ stall number 25 If you want good fabric go to Nadan Viswa @ Janathatex

We just happened by here one day and to be honest I wasn't expecting a great deal in this place but, it did surprise me with the array of fresh fruits on offer and the friendly stall holders are only too pleased to let you taste the different fruits which are delicious too. This market is actually housed in a square building sort of open planned and is on two levels housing just about everything including clothes, fruit, wooden ornaments, trinkets, oils, spices, etc, the only downside is they tend to sell the identical stuff and of course the clothes, bags etc are also copies but, good ones I might add but, just be careful though. Walking around I was acutely aware of an old guy following us, and of course he just happened to be a "Friend"  who would help us avoid the "Bad shops" naturally,  and trying to keep a straight face I kind of agreed. It turned out he was related to half the shop owners we visited and he was trying to get as much sales as he could for us, to be honest he was harmless and unfortunately for him he was dealing with a "Battle Hardened " World traveller who's visited markets a lot worse than this.  However we did buy some spices along with a huge bunch of bananas which I fed to the visiting monkeys back at my hotel, also do try the red bananas,as they're quite sweet as well as the grapes. Just walking around there is no snarling, shouting "In your face" sales pitch routine as you'd expect, and it's pretty relaxed too and do remember to haggle for everything, we also found the fish & meat side very interesting too, as well as watching the local cats & dogs sitting patiently awaiting the scraps.  Moving upstairs is more in the way of local crafts and clothes and this is where I got some of my fridge magnets as they were so cheap and the shopkeeper even dropped the price on these, I also tried to get a huge wooden elephant at another shop but, couldn't agree the price even with my "Friends" help, this guy was just being greedy and of course we had the old tourist mug sign above us. I do have to admit it was interesting watching what the locals were buying and one must wonder what their curries tasted like.? As for us we left pretty relaxed here considering in the past visiting some markets in the Middle East & Africa you feel like you've been 10 rounds with Mike Tyson and all for a ceramic vase or something stupid.!  A good tip here for anyone who's a bit nervous in these places, is to keep eye contact at all times when haggling, be prepared to walk away. And if you wear a pair of mirrored sunglasses it spooks them no end, as all they can see is there own face looking back it works every time. There is also a market across the road which is below the street  and we avoided this one like the plague, as it looked really third World and dirty..!
It is great to visit because you can see locals buying vegetables, fish , meat and fruits. And other stuff!

This market is very centrally located. We aren't used to haggling, so probably paid too much for everything, but compared with prices at home, we still felt we got bargains (saree, tea, oils, fruit, pashminas). We did fall for the old trick of a supposed porter at our hotel "recognising" us, and showing us around to get the "best" prices. A bit of fun mixing with local Kanyans regardless.
a shade like the old shopping mall in instumbul , but the small version. check the meat shops and fish shops, where cats on one end and dogs on the other waiting for scraps

the oldest market square in the city of kandy. it is small littler shopping stalls with anything and everything. the second floor is full of leather priducts and textile shops with bargains to be had. the friut stalls are just superb with tropical fruits aglore

This is an authentic market with a wide variety of offerings.  Produce, meat and fish on the ground level and handicrafts, textiles and leather goods upstairs.  Shop carefully and bargain as there's a significant markup for tourists

I was amazed by all of the selections at this wonderful market. I am still using a cream I purchased at one of the many pharmacies located here. What was really amazing were the fruit vendors. For 5 US dollars we purchased enough fruit for 3 people for two days. The vendor allowed us to sample all the exotic fruit you have heard of but never tasted. We had 4 varieties of mangoes, star fruit, passion fruit, jack fruit, pomegranate, durian...the vendors also had spices such as cinnamon and curries. My husband had a blocked ear so he went to the pharmacist for a remedy and he came back with ear drops. Overall, the prices were good and the fruit tasting was amazing.

Visited the Kandy Muncipial Market on early July 2014, its quite a crowded market , first floor is for everything from daily necessities ,local foods , tea ,traditional medicine, snacks ,and fruits.The top floor mainly textiles ,souvenirs, clothing ,books , shirts, hand drawn silks. You can bargain a bit on the lower floor and better if you push your bargaining skills when you shop on the top floor.price can reduce about 30-50 percent here. We bought some Tshirts ,hand drawn picture, a pashmina for a reasonable price.Tea bags ,local snacks ,and some fruits also bought at the lower level for a cheap price Market visits are always interesting ,thus we recommend this place for a visit.
